A couple of times in the past there have been discussions about 
evaluation schemes that are appropriate for comparing the relative 
efficacy of NEAT implementations and that can also be used to quantify 
the impact of adjustments and extensions to existing code. I reckon 
function regression fits the bill nicely here. In a past email I dreamt 
up a possible scheme that was based on the idea of NEAT trying to mimic 
the outputs of something akin to an electric circuit, I still like the 
idea but it's probably overkill for what we want right now. I've been 
experimenting with regression of some simple functions such as 
sine/square waves, simple curves, lines and combinations of these 
shapes, much like the functions that Mattias uses in his function 
regression demo, in fact I took some ideas from that demo to get me 
started. From this it's apparent that functions with a single input and 
output can be made to be as complex or as simple as we want, certainlly 
complex enought to challenge NEAT in its current forms.

Ok so I've devised a function that is basically a few lines and curves 
joined together (perhaps I'll called it Frankenstein Function #1) which 
isn't rediculously complex but at that same time seems to be challenging 
enough to be used as a benchmark. Here is a url to an image of the 
function (the black line) and SharpNEAT's best attempt so far at finding 
a fit (red line):

http://tinypic.com/esudex.jpg

 From left to right the function is made up of, a couple of steps, a 
straight rising line, a quarter of a sine wave, part of the curve an 
x^4, and finally part of the curve 1/x. Note that the red line isn't a 
very good fit!

Curently I'm trying to minimize a root of the error since the error is 
always less than 1.0. I haven't settled on which root yet, but if we can 
settle on a precise fitness function then I think (hope) this might 
serve as the basis for cross implementation comparisons. Other variables 
are:

- The sampling resolution, currently I'm using 64 but we can probably 
reduce that by at least a half without effecting this particular test's 
usefulness.
- The network topology. E.g. feedforward only?
- Network activation. How many activations?

The last two points should probably not be a strict requirement for the 
test since we are trying to find the best scheme, algorithm or whatever 
for fitting the function. So if e.g. you were to find that relaxing a 
recursive network gets a better score then that should stand as the best 
score. Or if you have a completely new algorithm where the number of 
activations is irrelevant then there are no issues comparing results.

Any thoughts? The function was just born out of scribbles on a bit of 
paper so if anyone has any ideas for a better or more appropriate 
function then I'm open to suggestions. Potentially Delphi NEAT and/or 
SLEAT might not have a problem with this function, so we might need 
something a bit more complex if Ian and/or Mattias were to find a good 
match.

Colin.
